A year after the pandemic canceled its signature tech and arts conference, SXSW, Austin...

id="page-json-ld-0">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/austin-covid-tech-migration-silicon-valley-16315291.php","url":"https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/austin-covid-tech-migration-silicon-valley-16315291.php","headline":"Austin was ‘the biggest winner’ of COVID tech migration. What happens to Silicon Valley?","articleSection":"Bay Area","publisher":{"@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"San Francisco Chronicle","url":"https://www.sfchronicle.com","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://www.sfchronicle.com/img/ldjson_logo.png","width":600,"height":60},"location":{"@type":"Place","name":"San Francisco Chronicle","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"San Francisco","addressRegion":"CA"}},"sameAs":["https://www.facebook.com/SFChronicle/","https://twitter.com/sfchronicle","https://www.instagram.com/sfchronicle/","https://www.linkedin.com/company/sfchronicle"]},"description":"A year after the pandemic canceled its signature tech and arts conference, SXSW, Austin...","image":{"@type":"imageObject","width":2048,"height":1364,"url":"https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/20/60/23/21169365/18/rawImage.jpg","thumbnailUrl":"https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/20/60/23/21169365/18/square_small.jpg","caption":"The view of the Austin skyline from the Pfluger Pedestrian Bridge in Austin, Texas."},"articleBody":"UPDATE: Tech workers leaving San Francisco have a new favorite destination AUSTIN, Texas — Texas’ capital has long been a tech pioneer, starting in the 1960s with IBM and Texas Instruments. In 1984, a University of Texas at Austin student named Michael Dell launched his PC company, which would become one of the largest computer manufacturers. But the rise of social media and mobile phones was concentrated in Silicon Valley, cementing the West Coast as the world’s biggest tech hub. Now, Austin is striving to win the next era of tech. A year after the pandemic canceled its signature tech and arts conference, SXSW, the city has gone from a harbinger of the crisis to one of its biggest winners, according to local businesses and economic data. Austin has regained 97% of its lost jobs from spring 2020, according to the Austin Chamber of Commerce. Unemployment was a seasonally adjusted 4.6% in May, down from a pandemic peak of around 12% in April 2020. Company relocations added 12,421 new jobs last year, a record high. The housing market is one of the hottest in the country, with demand soaring from out-of-state arrivals. Studies show there wasn’t a California exodus to Texas, but Austin has benefited from company expansions and tech migration. As Austin gained, the Bay Area lost. LinkedIn user data shows Austin had the highest net inflow of tech workers of any major U.S. city from May 2020 to April 2021, gaining 217 people for every 10,000 users. The Bay Area saw the biggest drop, losing 80 tech workers for every 10,000 users. “I didn’t think it could have grown any faster. And then somehow it did,” said Joshua Baer, CEO of Austin tech incubator Capital Factory. “COVID-19 broke a dam that was holding back thousands of even more people who were thinking about moving but held back by their job or other obligations.” “There were some big winners and some big losers in the COVID migration, and Austin was the biggest winner,” he said. Capital Factory works with about 120 new startups each year, and more than 20% of them are founded by ex-Californians, a percentage that’s growing, Baer said. As they did in the Bay Area, tech giants are transforming Austin’s cityscape. Google leased a giant sail-shaped tower under construction on the banks of the Colorado River, designed by the same architect as Salesforce Tower in San Francisco. Apple is building a second campus in North Austin. After sparring with Alameda County health officials during the pandemic, Tesla announced its next Gigafactory east of Austin with 5,000 workers, which is rising swiftly. Veterans of California tech are finding success in Austin. Tinder co-founder Whitney Wolfe Herd moved from Southern California to Austin in 2014 and started the female-focused dating app Bumble, which went public in February and is now valued at $6.8 billion. One of the pandemic’s biggest relocations came in December, when Silicon Valley stalwart Oracle moved its headquarters from Redwood City to a new campus in Austin after 44 years in the Bay Area. After a year of deserted streets and quiet offices across San Francisco and Silicon Valley, it was seen as another sign of the region’s slipping tech dominance. “Anyone who doesn’t believe that this latest departure isn’t a threat to California’s economy is a business climate denier,” Jim Wunderman, CEO of the Bay Area Council, a business group, said in a statement in December. “California for too long has willfully ignored our awful business climate, even as we’ve enjoyed incredible success and prosperity.” As downtown San Francisco hopes for recovery, partying is back in Austin. About half of office workers have returned in buildings managed by security firm Kastle Systems, compared with about a fifth in San Francisco, and they’re filling bars and barbecue joints. At the start of summer, live music was blasting and young residents zipping around on scooters — another California import from startups such as Lime and Bird. Austin is also dangling tax incentives to lure growth. Companies including Tesla, Apple and Samsung have packages from the city and Travis County worth up to tens of millions of dollars in property and payroll tax reimbursements. In contrast, the Bay Area rarely offers tax breaks to major projects and often adds fees to fund nearby transportation and affordable housing. Veronica Briseño, Austin’s economic development director, said the deals are structured to push companies to give community benefits. The city offers more incentive points for companies that adopt policies such as paid sick leave and working with minority-owned and women-owned vendors. Briseño also noted that the city has fewer incentive agreements compared with other Texas cities. The City Council, which signs off on deals, doesn’t “just offer anything to any company. They want to make sure if the company is embracing our community values,” she said. For all of Austin’s wins, few think it will eclipse Silicon Valley. “It’s not a zero-sum game, at least not for us,” Baer said. “Silicon Valley is not going to go away, either.” California’s economy has defied the doomsday scenarios at the beginning of the pandemic. A projected $54 billion budget deficit in May 2020 has flipped into a $75.7 billion surplus, with an additional $27 billion in federal aid to spend. A key part has been the boom of the tech industry, which has seen Silicon Valley’s biggest tech giants top $1 trillion market capitalization. Blockbuster initial public offerings from San Francisco’s Airbnb and DoorDash also swelled the state’s coffers. Even as tech giants Google and Apple expand with new Austin campuses, they’re investing more on the West Coast, too. Google plans to invest $1 billion in California real estate this year, and Apple signed the biggest Bay Area lease of the pandemic in May with a Sunnyvale expansion. As investors hunt for the next unicorn, Austin lagged behind seven other regions for venture capital deals in 2020. Deal activity totaled $2.3 billion compared with the Bay Area’s top spot of $61.5 billion and Los Angeles’ $19.3 billion, according to PitchBook, a research firm. But for someone trying to start a new company, Austin is becoming more attractive, said Ryan Broderick, an early executive at DoorDash. He left the Bay Area for Austin in 2018, becoming co-founder of real estate startup Darwin Homes, which focuses on single-family rental housing. The move made sense geographically, because the company wanted to focus on more affordable housing markets. Back in 2018, hiring was a challenge in Austin. “In the early days, it was not on par with the Bay Area, to be very honest. But I think that is now quickly changing.” he said. “There’s more talent moving every day.” The widespread adoption of remote work has also enabled Darwin to hire more broadly. About a third of the company’s 60 employees are in Austin, while the others are remote. In the past six months, about 10 of Broderick’s former DoorDash colleagues have also moved to Austin. The lack of state income tax was a plus, but the vibrant startup culture was also a big draw, Broderick said. The advantage of being in Silicon Valley near venture capital firms is also fading, he said. “Almost all of our capital has come from the Bay Area. We just tapped our network. They didn’t really care where we were starting our business or where we were,” he said. “I can imagine if you were starting a business in Austin with no network two years ago, it might have been a little more challenging, but today I don’t see that as an issue at all,” he said. “I think a lot of deals are getting done here by West Coast firms.” Previously, Broderick had resisted leaving California because he believed it would limit his opportunities. “I always thought there was a trade-off on my career. And I was never willing to make that, so I was tied to the Bay Area,” he said. “I don’t feel like those trade-offs exist now. And that’s the biggest thing that’s unlocking these other places. I can still pursue the same career path. And I don’t need to be tied to the Bay Area. That has changed the calculus. And I think Austin is the No. 1 benefiter of that kind of change. “I would not say that someone’s going to replace the Bay Area,” he said. “I think you’re just going to see more and more success stories coming out of new cities.” Roland Li is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer. Austin, Texas, constructing and leasing new buildings in the city and surrounding area.</p></span></span><span class="photoCredit c-gray600 block mt2 mr48"><span>Ilana Panich-Linsman/Special to The Chronicle</span></span></figcaption></figure><div class="pb20"><div id="everlit-auto-audio-widget" data-eid="item-102852" data-publication-id="pblc_kYW067sbmBR" class="y52px x100 tac fs16"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p class="MM_onlineOnly" title="CCI Online Only"><strong>UPDATE</strong>: <a href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/workers-leave-sf-ny-19416170.php" data-link="native" class="">Tech workers leaving San Francisco have a new favorite destination</a></p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>AUSTIN, Texas — Texas’ capital has long been a tech pioneer, starting in the 1960s with IBM and Texas Instruments. In 1984, a University of Texas at Austin student named Michael Dell launched his PC company, which would become one of the largest computer manufacturers. But the rise of social media and mobile phones was concentrated in Silicon Valley, cementing the West Coast as the world’s biggest tech hub.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Now, Austin is striving to win the next era of tech.</p></div><div class="pt16 sy16 bb bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class=""><p class="uiHeader11 f aic jcc ttu">Advertisement</p><p class="uiTextSmall f aic jcc">Article continues below this ad</p></div><div data-block-type="ad" data-small-id="A300" data-large-id="CONCERT1" data-unit="hnp-sfchronicle.com/article_dtc"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>A year after the pandemic canceled its signature tech and arts conference, SXSW, the city has gone from a harbinger of the crisis to one of its biggest winners, according to local businesses and economic data.</p></div><div class="pt16 sy16 bb bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class=""><p class="uiHeader11 f aic jcc ttu">Advertisement</p><p class="uiTextSmall f aic jcc">Article continues below this ad</p></div><div data-block-type="ad" data-small-id="CONCERT1" data-large-id="CONCERT2" data-unit="hnp-sfchronicle.com/article_dtc"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Austin has regained 97% of its lost jobs from spring 2020, according to the Austin Chamber of Commerce. Unemployment was a seasonally adjusted 4.6% in May, down from a pandemic peak of around 12% in April 2020. Company relocations added 12,421 new jobs last year, a record high. The housing market is <a href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/local/article/California-Austin-Texas-migration-home-prices-16275299.php" data-link="native" class="">one of the hottest in the country,</a> with demand soaring from out-of-state arrivals. Studies show <a href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/california/article/There-is-no-California-exodus-UC-studies-conclude-16299534.php" data-link="native" class="">there wasn’t a California exodus</a> to Texas, but Austin has benefited from company expansions and tech migration.</p></div><div data-block-type="embed" data-server-side-rendered="true" class="e1ogmilg x100 f fdc aic mb32"><iframe title="Jobs created in Austin due to relocation" aria-label="Bar Chart" id="datawrapper-chart-MLwN0" src="https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/MLwN0/1/" style="width: 0; min-width: 100% !important; border: none;" height="496"></iframe><script type="text/javascript">!function(){"use strict";window.addEventListener("message",(function(e){if(void 0!==e.data["datawrapper-height"]){var t=document.querySelectorAll("iframe");for(var a in e.data["datawrapper-height"])for(var r=0;r<t.length;r++){if(t[r].contentWindow===e.source)t[r].style.height=e.data["datawrapper-height"][a]+"px"}}}))}();
</script>
</div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>As Austin gained, the Bay Area lost. LinkedIn user data shows Austin had the highest net inflow of tech workers of any major U.S. city from May 2020 to April 2021, gaining 217 people for every 10,000 users. The Bay Area saw the biggest drop, losing 80 tech workers for every 10,000 users.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>“I didn’t think it could have grown any faster. And then somehow it did,” said Joshua Baer, CEO of Austin tech incubator Capital Factory. “COVID-19 broke a dam that was holding back thousands of even more people who were thinking about moving but held back by their job or other obligations.”</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>“There were some big winners and some big losers in the COVID migration, and Austin was the biggest winner,” he said.</p></div><div class="pt16 sy16 bb bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class=""><p class="uiHeader11 f aic jcc ttu">Advertisement</p><p class="uiTextSmall f aic jcc">Article continues below this ad</p></div><div data-block-type="ad" data-small-id="B300" data-unit="hnp-sfchronicle.com/article_dtc"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Capital Factory works with about 120 new startups each year, and more than 20% of them are founded by ex-Californians, a percentage that’s growing, Baer said.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>As they did in the Bay Area, tech giants are transforming Austin’s cityscape. Google <a href="https://austin.towers.net/googles-future-home-at-block-185-has-already-transformed-austins-skyline/" data-link="native" class="">leased a giant sail-shaped tower </a>under construction on the banks of the Colorado River, designed by the same architect as Salesforce Tower in San Francisco. Apple is building a second campus in North Austin. After sparring with Alameda County health officials during the pandemic, Tesla announced its next Gigafactory east of Austin with 5,000 workers, which is rising swiftly.</p></div><figure class="rel f m0 fdc -mx20 sm:mx0 x100vw sm:x100 mb32"><div class="rel x100 block"><picture><source type="image/webp" media="(min-width: 1260px)" 67vw, (min-width: 768px) 90vw, 100vw" style="aspect-ratio:3 / 2" class="x100 y100 opc bgpc ofcv bgscv block bg-gray200 mnh0px fill"/></picture></div><figcaption id="mediaCaptionAria" class="f fdc g2 rel pt8 px20 sm:px0"><span class="photoCaption c-gray700 ya block"><span><p>Google is expanding in Austin by leasing a new tower, but the company is also investing more than $1 billion in California real estate this year.</p></span></span><span class="photoCredit c-gray600 block mt2 mr48"><span>Ilana Panich-Linsman / Special to The Chronicle</span></span></figcaption></figure><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Veterans of California tech are finding success in Austin. Tinder co-founder Whitney Wolfe Herd moved from Southern California to Austin in 2014 and started the female-focused dating app Bumble, which went public in February and is now valued at $6.8 billion.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>One of the pandemic’s biggest relocations came in December, when Silicon Valley stalwart Oracle moved its headquarters from Redwood City to a <a href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Oracle-to-move-headquarters-from-Redwood-City-to-15795539.php" data-link="native" class="">new campus in Austin</a> after 44 years in the Bay Area. After a year of deserted streets and quiet offices across San Francisco and Silicon Valley, it was seen as another sign of the region’s slipping tech dominance.</p></div><div class="pt16 sy16 bb bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class=""><p class="uiHeader11 f aic jcc ttu">Advertisement</p><p class="uiTextSmall f aic jcc">Article continues below this ad</p></div><div data-block-type="ad" data-small-id="CONCERT2" data-unit="hnp-sfchronicle.com/article_dtc"></div></div><div data-block-type="embed" data-server-side-rendered="true" class="e1ogmilg x100 f fdc aic mb32"><iframe title="Pandemic job rebound" aria-label="Interactive line chart" id="datawrapper-chart-HCxeP" src="https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/HCxeP/3/" style="width: 0; min-width: 100% !important; border: none;" height="500"></iframe><script type="text/javascript">!function(){"use strict";window.addEventListener("message",(function(e){if(void 0!==e.data["datawrapper-height"]){var t=document.querySelectorAll("iframe");for(var a in e.data["datawrapper-height"])for(var r=0;r<t.length;r++){if(t[r].contentWindow===e.source)t[r].style.height=e.data["datawrapper-height"][a]+"px"}}}))}();
</script>
</div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>“Anyone who doesn’t believe that this latest departure isn’t a threat to California’s economy is a business climate denier,” Jim Wunderman, CEO of the Bay Area Council, a business group, said in a statement in December. “California for too long has willfully ignored our awful business climate, even as we’ve enjoyed incredible success and prosperity.”</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>As downtown San Francisco hopes for recovery, partying is back in Austin. About half of office workers have returned in buildings managed by security firm Kastle Systems, compared with about a fifth in San Francisco, and they’re filling bars and barbecue joints. At the start of summer, live music was blasting and young residents zipping around on scooters — another California import from startups such as Lime and Bird.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Austin is also dangling tax incentives to lure growth. Companies including Tesla, Apple and Samsung have packages from the city and Travis County worth up to tens of millions of dollars in property and payroll tax reimbursements. In contrast, the Bay Area rarely offers tax breaks to major projects and often adds fees to fund nearby transportation and affordable housing.</p></div><div data-block-type="inlinerecirculation" class="pb32"><div class="f fdc sy0"><span><div class="f aic mb16"><div class="defaultSm bt bw2 ttc pt8 x100"><h2 class="wsn">Real Estate</h2></div></div></span><div><div class="fdc jcb"><article class="grid col1-min"><div class="f fdc sy8 mr8 col1 row1 jce"><h2 class="owa c-black tertiary fs16 sm:fs18"><a href="/california/article/There-is-no-California-exodus-UC-studies-conclude-16299534.php" data-link="native" class="tdn hover:o70 td300">There is no California exodus, UC studies conclude</a></h2></div><div class="grid sy8 row2 col1span2"><a href="/california/article/There-is-no-California-exodus-UC-studies-conclude-16299534.php" data-link="native" class="c-gray700 m0 abstract fs16 lh13 none tdn hover:o70 td300"><div data-block-type="text" data-server-side-rendered="true" class="r12zgbl0">A new UC survey concludes there’s no California exodus, with only 23% of more than 3,000...</div></a></div><div class="block col2 row1 ml8 x90px xs:x120px sm:x180px lg:x88px"><a href="/california/article/There-is-no-California-exodus-UC-studies-conclude-16299534.php" data-link="native" class=""><div class="rel x100 block"><picture><source type="image/webp" media="(min-width: 1048px)" srcSet="https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/20/71/44/21207339/13/ratio3x2_80.webp"/><source type="image/webp" media="(max-width: 1047px)" srcSet="https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/20/71/44/21207339/13/ratio3x2_160.webp"/><img alt="The California State flag flies beside a sign for its sister city Split outside City Hall, in Los Angeles. neighborhoods, thanks to the ‘doughnut’ effect</a></h2></div><div class="grid sy8 row2 col1span2"><a href="/local/article/Home-values-sank-in-these-S-F-neighborhoods-16243814.php" data-link="native" data-dropcap="false"><p>Veronica Briseño, Austin’s economic development director, said the deals are structured to push companies to give community benefits. The city offers more incentive points for companies that adopt policies such as paid sick leave and working with minority-owned and women-owned vendors. Briseño also noted that the city has fewer incentive agreements compared with other Texas cities.</p></div><div class="pt16 sy16 bb bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class=""><p class="uiHeader11 f aic jcc ttu">Advertisement</p><p class="uiTextSmall f aic jcc">Article continues below this ad</p></div><div data-block-type="ad" data-small-id="S300" data-unit="hnp-sfchronicle.com/article_dtc"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>The City Council, which signs off on deals, doesn’t “just offer anything to any company. They want to make sure if the company is embracing our community values,” she said.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>For all of Austin’s wins, few think it will eclipse Silicon Valley. “It’s not a zero-sum game, at least not for us,” Baer said. “Silicon Valley is not going to go away, either.”</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>California’s economy has defied the doomsday scenarios at the beginning of the pandemic. A projected $54 billion budget deficit in May 2020 has flipped into a $75.7 billion surplus, with an additional $27 billion in federal aid to spend.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>A key part has been the boom of the tech industry, which has seen Silicon Valley’s biggest tech giants top $1 trillion market capitalization. Blockbuster initial public offerings from San Francisco’s Airbnb and DoorDash also swelled the state’s coffers.</p></div><figure class="rel f m0 fdc -mx20 sm:mx0 x100vw sm:x100 mb32"><div class="rel x100 block"><picture><source type="image/webp" media="(min-width: 1260px)" srcSet="https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/21/00/66/21237171/10/ratio3x2_960.webp"/><source type="image/webp" media="(min-width: Area.</p></span></span><span class="photoCredit c-gray600 block mt2 mr48"><span>Ilana Panich-Linsman, austin06xx_housing / Ilana Panich-Linsman</span></span></figcaption></figure><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Even as tech giants Google and Apple expand with new Austin campuses, they’re investing more on the West Coast, too. Google plans to invest $1 billion in California real estate this year, and Apple signed the biggest Bay Area lease of the pandemic in May with a Sunnyvale expansion.</p></div><div><div data-block-type="ad" data-unit="hnp-sfchronicle.com/article_dtc"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>As investors hunt for the next unicorn, Austin lagged behind seven other regions for venture capital deals in 2020. Deal activity totaled $2.3 billion compared with the Bay Area’s top spot of $61.5 billion and Los Angeles’ $19.3 billion, according to PitchBook, a research firm.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>But for someone trying to start a new company, Austin is becoming more attractive, said Ryan Broderick, an early executive at DoorDash. He left the Bay Area for Austin in 2018, becoming co-founder of real estate startup Darwin Homes, which focuses on single-family rental housing. The move made sense geographically, because the company wanted to focus on more affordable housing markets.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Back in 2018, hiring was a challenge in Austin.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>“In the early days, it was not on par with the Bay Area, to be very honest. But I think that is now quickly changing.” he said. “There’s more talent moving every day.”</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>The widespread adoption of remote work has also enabled Darwin to hire more broadly. About a third of the company’s 60 employees are in Austin, while the others are remote.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>In the past six months, about 10 of Broderick’s former DoorDash colleagues have also moved to Austin. The lack of state income tax was a plus, but the vibrant startup culture was also a big draw, Broderick said.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>The advantage of being in Silicon Valley near venture capital firms is also fading, he said.</p></div><figure class="rel f m0 fdc -mx20 sm:mx0 x100vw sm:x100 mb32"><div class="rel x100 block"><picture><source type="image/webp" media="(min-width: 1260px)" srcSet="https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/21/00/66/21237175/7/ratio3x2_960.webp"/><source type="image/webp" block mt2 mr48"><span>Ilana Panich-Linsman / Special to The Chronicle</span></span></figcaption></figure><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>“Almost all of our capital has come from the Bay Area. We just tapped our network. They didn’t really care where we were starting our business or where we were,” he said.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>“I can imagine if you were starting a business in Austin with no network two years ago, it might have been a little more challenging, but today I don’t see that as an issue at all,” he said. “I think a lot of deals are getting done here by West Coast firms.”</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Previously, Broderick had resisted leaving California because he believed it would limit his opportunities.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>“I always thought there was a trade-off on my career. And I was never willing to make that, so I was tied to the Bay Area,” he said. “I don’t feel like those trade-offs exist now. And that’s the biggest thing that’s unlocking these other places. I can still pursue the same career path. And I don’t need to be tied to the Bay Area. That has changed the calculus. And I think Austin is the No. 1 benefiter of that kind of change.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>“I would not say that someone’s going to replace the Bay Area,” he said. “I think you’re just going to see more and more success stories coming out of new cities.”</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Roland Li is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer. Email: <a href="mailto:roland.li@sfchronicle.com" data-link="native" class="">roland.li@sfchronicle.com</a> Twitter: <a href="https://twitter.com/rolandlisf" data-link="native" class="">@rolandlisf</a></p></div><div class="y1px x100 abs bgn top"></div><div style="top:25%" class="y1px x100 abs bgn"></div><div style="top:50%" class="y1px x100 abs bgn"></div><div style="top:75%" class="y1px x100 abs bgn"></div><div class="y1px x100 abs bgn bottom"></div></article></div><div class="package"><span class="mb16 block"><span class="smallTimestamp lg:largeTimestamp pb1 c-gray600"><time dateTime="2021-07-14 15:58:41">July 14, 2021</time></span><span class="smallTimestamp lg:largeTimestamp pb1 c-gray600"><span class="px8">|</span>Updated<!-- --> <time dateTime="2021-07-18 12:59:30">July 18, 2021 12:59 p.m.</time></span></span><div><div class="py16"><div class="grid template-row2a temp-col-60px-1fr mnh100 g16 sm:g24"><div class="mnw48px noshrink col1 xs:row1span"><div class="rel x100 block"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcSet="https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/06/33/27/18462162/5/ratio1x1_150.webp"/><img title="Photo of Roland Li" alt="Photo of Roland Li" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/06/33/27/18462162/5/ratio1x1_80.jpg 80w" sizes="48px" style="aspect-ratio:1 / 1" class="x100 br50 y100 opc bgpc ofcv bgscv block bg-gray200 mnh0px fill"/></picture></div></div><div class="f fdc jcc xs:jcs xs:pt6 col2span2 col1span3"><div class="primarySm mb2 xs:mb8"><a href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/author/roland-li/" data-link="native" class="tdu tuo2px">Roland Li</a></div><div class="cardByline ttu c-gray600">Business Reporter</div></div><div class="row3 col1Span xs:row2 xs:col1span4 sm:col1span4 xs:mt8 sm:mt0"><h2 data-server-side-rendered="true" class="r12zgbl0 deckSm fs16 c-gray700 sy16"><p>Roland Li covers commercial real estate for the business desk, focusing on the Bay Area office and retail sectors.</p>
<p>He was previously a reporter at San Francisco Business Times, where he won one award from the California News Publishers Association and three from the National Association of Real Estate Editors.</p>
<p>He is the author of “Good Luck Have Fun: The Rise of eSports," a 2016 book on the history of the competitive video game industry. Before moving to the Bay Area in 2015, he studied and worked in New York. He freelanced for the Wall Street Journal, the New York Times and other local publications. His hobbies include swimming and urban photography.</p></h2></div><span class="col1Span xs:col4 xs:jsfe"><div class="sx8 f"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/SFChronicle/" data-link="native" What happens to Silicon Valley?","articleSection":"Bay Area","publisher":{"@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"San Francisco Chronicle","url":"https://www.sfchronicle.com","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://www.sfchronicle.com/img/ldjson_logo.png","width":600,"height":60},"location":{"@type":"Place","name":"San Francisco Chronicle","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"San Francisco","addressRegion":"CA"}},"sameAs":["https://www.facebook.com/SFChronicle/","https://twitter.com/sfchronicle","https://www.instagram.com/sfchronicle/","https://www.linkedin.com/company/sfchronicle"]},"description":"A year after the pandemic canceled its signature tech and arts conference, SXSW, Austin...","image":{"@type":"imageObject","width":2048,"height":1364,"url":"https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/20/60/23/21169365/18/rawImage.jpg","thumbnailUrl":"https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/20/60/23/21169365/18/square_small.jpg","caption":"The view of the Austin skyline from the Pfluger Pedestrian Bridge in Austin, Texas."},"articleBody":"UPDATE: Tech workers leaving San Francisco have a new favorite destination AUSTIN, Texas — Texas’ capital has long been a tech pioneer, starting in the 1960s with IBM and Texas Instruments. In 1984, a University of Texas at Austin student named Michael Dell launched his PC company, which would become one of the largest computer manufacturers. But the rise of social media and mobile phones was concentrated in Silicon Valley, cementing the West Coast as the world’s biggest tech hub. Now, Austin is striving to win the next era of tech. A year after the pandemic canceled its signature tech and arts conference, SXSW, the city has gone from a harbinger of the crisis to one of its biggest winners, according to local businesses and economic data. Austin has regained 97% of its lost jobs from spring 2020, according to the Austin Chamber of Commerce. Unemployment was a seasonally adjusted 4.6% in May, down from a pandemic peak of around 12% in April 2020. Company relocations added 12,421 new jobs last year, a record high. The housing market is one of the hottest in the country, with demand soaring from out-of-state arrivals. Studies show there wasn’t a California exodus to Texas, but Austin has benefited from company expansions and tech migration. As Austin gained, the Bay Area lost. LinkedIn user data shows Austin had the highest net inflow of tech workers of any major U.S. city from May 2020 to April 2021, gaining 217 people for every 10,000 users. The Bay Area saw the biggest drop, losing 80 tech workers for every 10,000 users. “I didn’t think it could have grown any faster. And then somehow it did,” said Joshua Baer, CEO of Austin tech incubator Capital Factory. “COVID-19 broke a dam that was holding back thousands of even more people who were thinking about moving but held back by their job or other obligations.” “There were some big winners and some big losers in the COVID migration, and Austin was the biggest winner,” he said. Capital Factory works with about 120 new startups each year, and more than 20% of them are founded by ex-Californians, a percentage that’s growing, Baer said. As they did in the Bay Area, tech giants are transforming Austin’s cityscape. Google leased a giant sail-shaped tower under construction on the banks of the Colorado River, designed by the same architect as Salesforce Tower in San Francisco. Apple is building a second campus in North Austin. After sparring with Alameda County health officials during the pandemic, Tesla announced its next Gigafactory east of Austin with 5,000 workers, which is rising swiftly. Veterans of California tech are finding success in Austin. Tinder co-founder Whitney Wolfe Herd moved from Southern California to Austin in 2014 and started the female-focused dating app Bumble, which went public in February and is now valued at $6.8 billion. One of the pandemic’s biggest relocations came in December, when Silicon Valley stalwart Oracle moved its headquarters from Redwood City to a new campus in Austin after 44 years in the Bay Area. After a year of deserted streets and quiet offices across San Francisco and Silicon Valley, it was seen as another sign of the region’s slipping tech dominance. “Anyone who doesn’t believe that this latest departure isn’t a threat to California’s economy is a business climate denier,” Jim Wunderman, CEO of the Bay Area Council, a business group, said in a statement in December. “California for too long has willfully ignored our awful business climate, even as we’ve enjoyed incredible success and prosperity.” As downtown San Francisco hopes for recovery, partying is back in Austin. About half of office workers have returned in buildings managed by security firm Kastle Systems, compared with about a fifth in San Francisco, and they’re filling bars and barbecue joints. At the start of summer, live music was blasting and young residents zipping around on scooters — another California import from startups such as Lime and Bird. Austin is also dangling tax incentives to lure growth. Companies including Tesla, Apple and Samsung have packages from the city and Travis County worth up to tens of millions of dollars in property and payroll tax reimbursements. In contrast, the Bay Area rarely offers tax breaks to major projects and often adds fees to fund nearby transportation and affordable housing. Veronica Briseño, Austin’s economic development director, said the deals are structured to push companies to give community benefits. The city offers more incentive points for companies that adopt policies such as paid sick leave and working with minority-owned and women-owned vendors. Briseño also noted that the city has fewer incentive agreements compared with other Texas cities. The City Council, which signs off on deals, doesn’t “just offer anything to any company. They want to make sure if the company is embracing our community values,” she said. For all of Austin’s wins, few think it will eclipse Silicon Valley. “It’s not a zero-sum game, at least not for us,” Baer said. “Silicon Valley is not going to go away, either.” California’s economy has defied the doomsday scenarios at the beginning of the pandemic. A projected $54 billion budget deficit in May 2020 has flipped into a $75.7 billion surplus, with an additional $27 billion in federal aid to spend. A key part has been the boom of the tech industry, which has seen Silicon Valley’s biggest tech giants top $1 trillion market capitalization. Blockbuster initial public offerings from San Francisco’s Airbnb and DoorDash also swelled the state’s coffers. Even as tech giants Google and Apple expand with new Austin campuses, they’re investing more on the West Coast, too. Google plans to invest $1 billion in California real estate this year, and Apple signed the biggest Bay Area lease of the pandemic in May with a Sunnyvale expansion. As investors hunt for the next unicorn, Austin lagged behind seven other regions for venture capital deals in 2020. Deal activity totaled $2.3 billion compared with the Bay Area’s top spot of $61.5 billion and Los Angeles’ $19.3 billion, according to PitchBook, a research firm. But for someone trying to start a new company, Austin is becoming more attractive, said Ryan Broderick, an early executive at DoorDash. He left the Bay Area for Austin in 2018, becoming co-founder of real estate startup Darwin Homes, which focuses on single-family rental housing. The move made sense geographically, because the company wanted to focus on more affordable housing markets. Back in 2018, hiring was a challenge in Austin. “In the early days, it was not on par with the Bay Area, to be very honest. But I think that is now quickly changing.” he said. “There’s more talent moving every day.” The widespread adoption of remote work has also enabled Darwin to hire more broadly. About a third of the company’s 60 employees are in Austin, while the others are remote. In the past six months, about 10 of Broderick’s former DoorDash colleagues have also moved to Austin. The lack of state income tax was a plus, but the vibrant startup culture was also a big draw, Broderick said. The advantage of being in Silicon Valley near venture capital firms is also fading, he said. “Almost all of our capital has come from the Bay Area. We just tapped our network. They didn’t really care where we were starting our business or where we were,” he said. “I can imagine if you were starting a business in Austin with no network two years ago, it might have been a little more challenging, but today I don’t see that as an issue at all,” he said. “I think a lot of deals are getting done here by West Coast firms.” Previously, Broderick had resisted leaving California because he believed it would limit his opportunities. “I always thought there was a trade-off on my career. And I was never willing to make that, so I was tied to the Bay Area,” he said. “I don’t feel like those trade-offs exist now. And that’s the biggest thing that’s unlocking these other places. I can still pursue the same career path. And I don’t need to be tied to the Bay Area. That has changed the calculus. And I think Austin is the No. 1 benefiter of that kind of change. “I would not say that someone’s going to replace the Bay Area,” he said. “I think you’re just going to see more and more success stories coming out of new cities.” Roland Li is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer. readabilityObject.title: Austin was ‘the biggest winner’ of COVID tech migration. What happens to Silicon Valley?
readabilityObject.content:
AUSTIN, Texas — Texas’ capital has long been a tech pioneer, starting in the 1960s with IBM and Texas Instruments. In 1984, a University of Texas at Austin student named Michael Dell launched his PC company, which would become one of the largest computer manufacturers. But the rise of social media and mobile phones was concentrated in Silicon Valley, cementing the West Coast as the world’s biggest tech hub.

Now, Austin is striving to win the next era of tech.

Article continues below this ad

A year after the pandemic canceled its signature tech and arts conference, SXSW, the city has gone from a harbinger of the crisis to one of its biggest winners, according to local businesses and economic data.

Article continues below this ad

Austin has regained 97% of its lost jobs from spring 2020, according to the Austin Chamber of Commerce. Unemployment was a seasonally adjusted 4.6% in May, down from a pandemic peak of around 12% in April 2020. Company relocations added 12,421 new jobs last year, a record high. The housing market is one of the hottest in the country, with demand soaring from out-of-state arrivals. Studies show there wasn’t a California exodus to Texas, but Austin has benefited from company expansions and tech migration.

As Austin gained, the Bay Area lost. LinkedIn user data shows Austin had the highest net inflow of tech workers of any major U.S. city from May 2020 to April 2021, gaining 217 people for every 10,000 users. The Bay Area saw the biggest drop, losing 80 tech workers for every 10,000 users.

“I didn’t think it could have grown any faster. And then somehow it did,” said Joshua Baer, CEO of Austin tech incubator Capital Factory. “COVID-19 broke a dam that was holding back thousands of even more people who were thinking about moving but held back by their job or other obligations.”

“There were some big winners and some big losers in the COVID migration, and Austin was the biggest winner,” he said.

Article continues below this ad

Capital Factory works with about 120 new startups each year, and more than 20% of them are founded by ex-Californians, a percentage that’s growing, Baer said.

As they did in the Bay Area, tech giants are transforming Austin’s cityscape. Google leased a giant sail-shaped tower under construction on the banks of the Colorado River, designed by the same architect as Salesforce Tower in San Francisco. Apple is building a second campus in North Austin. After sparring with Alameda County health officials during the pandemic, Tesla announced its next Gigafactory east of Austin with 5,000 workers, which is rising swiftly.

Veterans of California tech are finding success in Austin. Tinder co-founder Whitney Wolfe Herd moved from Southern California to Austin in 2014 and started the female-focused dating app Bumble, which went public in February and is now valued at $6.8 billion.

One of the pandemic’s biggest relocations came in December, when Silicon Valley stalwart Oracle moved its headquarters from Redwood City to a new campus in Austin after 44 years in the Bay Area. After a year of deserted streets and quiet offices across San Francisco and Silicon Valley, it was seen as another sign of the region’s slipping tech dominance.

Article continues below this ad

“Anyone who doesn’t believe that this latest departure isn’t a threat to California’s economy is a business climate denier,” Jim Wunderman, CEO of the Bay Area Council, a business group, said in a statement in December. “California for too long has willfully ignored our awful business climate, even as we’ve enjoyed incredible success and prosperity.”

As downtown San Francisco hopes for recovery, partying is back in Austin. About half of office workers have returned in buildings managed by security firm Kastle Systems, compared with about a fifth in San Francisco, and they’re filling bars and barbecue joints. At the start of summer, live music was blasting and young residents zipping around on scooters — another California import from startups such as Lime and Bird.

Austin is also dangling tax incentives to lure growth. Companies including Tesla, Apple and Samsung have packages from the city and Travis County worth up to tens of millions of dollars in property and payroll tax reimbursements. In contrast, the Bay Area rarely offers tax breaks to major projects and often adds fees to fund nearby transportation and affordable housing.

Real Estate

Veronica Briseño, Austin’s economic development director, said the deals are structured to push companies to give community benefits. The city offers more incentive points for companies that adopt policies such as paid sick leave and working with minority-owned and women-owned vendors. Briseño also noted that the city has fewer incentive agreements compared with other Texas cities.

Article continues below this ad

The City Council, which signs off on deals, doesn’t “just offer anything to any company. They want to make sure if the company is embracing our community values,” she said.

For all of Austin’s wins, few think it will eclipse Silicon Valley. “It’s not a zero-sum game, at least not for us,” Baer said. “Silicon Valley is not going to go away, either.”

California’s economy has defied the doomsday scenarios at the beginning of the pandemic. A projected $54 billion budget deficit in May 2020 has flipped into a $75.7 billion surplus, with an additional $27 billion in federal aid to spend.

A key part has been the boom of the tech industry, which has seen Silicon Valley’s biggest tech giants top $1 trillion market capitalization. Blockbuster initial public offerings from San Francisco’s Airbnb and DoorDash also swelled the state’s coffers.

Even as tech giants Google and Apple expand with new Austin campuses, they’re investing more on the West Coast, too. Google plans to invest $1 billion in California real estate this year, and Apple signed the biggest Bay Area lease of the pandemic in May with a Sunnyvale expansion.

As investors hunt for the next unicorn, Austin lagged behind seven other regions for venture capital deals in 2020. Deal activity totaled $2.3 billion compared with the Bay Area’s top spot of $61.5 billion and Los Angeles’ $19.3 billion, according to PitchBook, a research firm.

But for someone trying to start a new company, Austin is becoming more attractive, said Ryan Broderick, an early executive at DoorDash. He left the Bay Area for Austin in 2018, becoming co-founder of real estate startup Darwin Homes, which focuses on single-family rental housing. The move made sense geographically, because the company wanted to focus on more affordable housing markets.

Back in 2018, hiring was a challenge in Austin.

“In the early days, it was not on par with the Bay Area, to be very honest. But I think that is now quickly changing.” he said. “There’s more talent moving every day.”

The widespread adoption of remote work has also enabled Darwin to hire more broadly. About a third of the company’s 60 employees are in Austin, while the others are remote.

In the past six months, about 10 of Broderick’s former DoorDash colleagues have also moved to Austin. The lack of state income tax was a plus, but the vibrant startup culture was also a big draw, Broderick said.

The advantage of being in Silicon Valley near venture capital firms is also fading, he said.

“Almost all of our capital has come from the Bay Area. We just tapped our network. They didn’t really care where we were starting our business or where we were,” he said.

“I can imagine if you were starting a business in Austin with no network two years ago, it might have been a little more challenging, but today I don’t see that as an issue at all,” he said. “I think a lot of deals are getting done here by West Coast firms.”

Previously, Broderick had resisted leaving California because he believed it would limit his opportunities.

“I always thought there was a trade-off on my career. And I was never willing to make that, so I was tied to the Bay Area,” he said. “I don’t feel like those trade-offs exist now. And that’s the biggest thing that’s unlocking these other places. I can still pursue the same career path. And I don’t need to be tied to the Bay Area. That has changed the calculus. And I think Austin is the No. 1 benefiter of that kind of change.

“I would not say that someone’s going to replace the Bay Area,” he said. “I think you’re just going to see more and more success stories coming out of new cities.”

Roland Li is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer. Email: roland.li@sfchronicle.com Twitter: @rolandlisf

July 14, 2021|Updated July 18, 2021 12:59 p.m.

Roland Li covers commercial real estate for the business desk, focusing on the Bay Area office and retail sectors.

He was previously a reporter at San Francisco Business Times, where he won one award from the California News Publishers Association and three from the National Association of Real Estate Editors.

He is the author of “Good Luck Have Fun: The Rise of eSports," a 2016 book on the history of the competitive video game industry. Before moving to the Bay Area in 2015, he studied and worked in New York. He freelanced for the Wall Street Journal, the New York Times and other local publications. His hobbies include swimming and urban photography.

jsonLd.headline: Austin was ‘the biggest winner’ of COVID tech migration. What happens to Silicon Valley?
jsonLd.description: A year after the pandemic canceled its signature tech and arts conference, SXSW, Austin...

image.caption: The view of the Austin skyline from the Pfluger Pedestrian Bridge in Austin, Texas.

jsonLd.articleBody: UPDATE: Tech workers leaving San Francisco have a new favorite destination AUSTIN, Texas — Texas’ capital has long been a tech pioneer, starting in the 1960s with IBM and Texas Instruments. In 1984, a University of Texas at Austin student named Michael Dell launched his PC company, which would become one of the largest computer manufacturers. But the rise of social media and mobile phones was concentrated in Silicon Valley, cementing the West Coast as the world’s biggest tech hub. Now, Austin is striving to win the next era of tech. A year after the pandemic canceled its signature tech and arts conference, SXSW, the city has gone from a harbinger of the crisis to one of its biggest winners, according to local businesses and economic data. Austin has regained 97% of its lost jobs from spring 2020, according to the Austin Chamber of Commerce. Unemployment was a seasonally adjusted 4.6% in May, down from a pandemic peak of around 12% in April 2020. Company relocations added 12,421 new jobs last year, a record high. The housing market is one of the hottest in the country, with demand soaring from out-of-state arrivals. Studies show there wasn’t a California exodus to Texas, but Austin has benefited from company expansions and tech migration. As Austin gained, the Bay Area lost. LinkedIn user data shows Austin had the highest net inflow of tech workers of any major U.S. city from May 2020 to April 2021, gaining 217 people for every 10,000 users. The Bay Area saw the biggest drop, losing 80 tech workers for every 10,000 users. “I didn’t think it could have grown any faster. And then somehow it did,” said Joshua Baer, CEO of Austin tech incubator Capital Factory. “COVID-19 broke a dam that was holding back thousands of even more people who were thinking about moving but held back by their job or other obligations.” “There were some big winners and some big losers in the COVID migration, and Austin was the biggest winner,” he said. Capital Factory works with about 120 new startups each year, and more than 20% of them are founded by ex-Californians, a percentage that’s growing, Baer said. As they did in the Bay Area, tech giants are transforming Austin’s cityscape. Google leased a giant sail-shaped tower under construction on the banks of the Colorado River, designed by the same architect as Salesforce Tower in San Francisco. Apple is building a second campus in North Austin. After sparring with Alameda County health officials during the pandemic, Tesla announced its next Gigafactory east of Austin with 5,000 workers, which is rising swiftly. Veterans of California tech are finding success in Austin. Tinder co-founder Whitney Wolfe Herd moved from Southern California to Austin in 2014 and started the female-focused dating app Bumble, which went public in February and is now valued at $6.8 billion. One of the pandemic’s biggest relocations came in December, when Silicon Valley stalwart Oracle moved its headquarters from Redwood City to a new campus in Austin after 44 years in the Bay Area. After a year of deserted streets and quiet offices across San Francisco and Silicon Valley, it was seen as another sign of the region’s slipping tech dominance. “Anyone who doesn’t believe that this latest departure isn’t a threat to California’s economy is a business climate denier,” Jim Wunderman, CEO of the Bay Area Council, a business group, said in a statement in December. “California for too long has willfully ignored our awful business climate, even as we’ve enjoyed incredible success and prosperity.” As downtown San Francisco hopes for recovery, partying is back in Austin. About half of office workers have returned in buildings managed by security firm Kastle Systems, compared with about a fifth in San Francisco, and they’re filling bars and barbecue joints. At the start of summer, live music was blasting and young residents zipping around on scooters — another California import from startups such as Lime and Bird. Austin is also dangling tax incentives to lure growth. Companies including Tesla, Apple and Samsung have packages from the city and Travis County worth up to tens of millions of dollars in property and payroll tax reimbursements. In contrast, the Bay Area rarely offers tax breaks to major projects and often adds fees to fund nearby transportation and affordable housing. Veronica Briseño, Austin’s economic development director, said the deals are structured to push companies to give community benefits. The city offers more incentive points for companies that adopt policies such as paid sick leave and working with minority-owned and women-owned vendors. Briseño also noted that the city has fewer incentive agreements compared with other Texas cities. The City Council, which signs off on deals, doesn’t “just offer anything to any company. They want to make sure if the company is embracing our community values,” she said. For all of Austin’s wins, few think it will eclipse Silicon Valley. “It’s not a zero-sum game, at least not for us,” Baer said. “Silicon Valley is not going to go away, either.” California’s economy has defied the doomsday scenarios at the beginning of the pandemic. A projected $54 billion budget deficit in May 2020 has flipped into a $75.7 billion surplus, with an additional $27 billion in federal aid to spend. A key part has been the boom of the tech industry, which has seen Silicon Valley’s biggest tech giants top $1 trillion market capitalization. Blockbuster initial public offerings from San Francisco’s Airbnb and DoorDash also swelled the state’s coffers. Even as tech giants Google and Apple expand with new Austin campuses, they’re investing more on the West Coast, too. Google plans to invest $1 billion in California real estate this year, and Apple signed the biggest Bay Area lease of the pandemic in May with a Sunnyvale expansion. As investors hunt for the next unicorn, Austin lagged behind seven other regions for venture capital deals in 2020. Deal activity totaled $2.3 billion compared with the Bay Area’s top spot of $61.5 billion and Los Angeles’ $19.3 billion, according to PitchBook, a research firm. But for someone trying to start a new company, Austin is becoming more attractive, said Ryan Broderick, an early executive at DoorDash. He left the Bay Area for Austin in 2018, becoming co-founder of real estate startup Darwin Homes, which focuses on single-family rental housing. The move made sense geographically, because the company wanted to focus on more affordable housing markets. Back in 2018, hiring was a challenge in Austin. “In the early days, it was not on par with the Bay Area, to be very honest. But I think that is now quickly changing.” he said. “There’s more talent moving every day.” The widespread adoption of remote work has also enabled Darwin to hire more broadly. About a third of the company’s 60 employees are in Austin, while the others are remote. In the past six months, about 10 of Broderick’s former DoorDash colleagues have also moved to Austin. The lack of state income tax was a plus, but the vibrant startup culture was also a big draw, Broderick said. The advantage of being in Silicon Valley near venture capital firms is also fading, he said. “Almost all of our capital has come from the Bay Area. We just tapped our network. They didn’t really care where we were starting our business or where we were,” he said. “I can imagine if you were starting a business in Austin with no network two years ago, it might have been a little more challenging, but today I don’t see that as an issue at all,” he said. “I think a lot of deals are getting done here by West Coast firms.” Previously, Broderick had resisted leaving California because he believed it would limit his opportunities. “I always thought there was a trade-off on my career. And I was never willing to make that, so I was tied to the Bay Area,” he said. “I don’t feel like those trade-offs exist now. And that’s the biggest thing that’s unlocking these other places. I can still pursue the same career path. And I don’t need to be tied to the Bay Area. That has changed the calculus. And I think Austin is the No. 1 benefiter of that kind of change. “I would not say that someone’s going to replace the Bay Area,” he said. “I think you’re just going to see more and more success stories coming out of new cities.” Roland Li is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer. Email: roland.li@sfchronicle.com Twitter: @rolandlisf
